columns.text: In this exercise, we are to discuss the sustainable growth rate and the two formulas used to arrive at the rate under the two assumptions of the use of equity.

## Sustainable Growth Rate
\
The sustainable growth rate is referred to as the maximum rate of growth attainable by the company without the need for external equity financing and at the same time, maintaining the debt-to-equity at a constant ratio.

The sustainable growth rate is the maximum rate of growth that a company would attain which requires the firm not to increase the company equity. While the ROE is the ratio of the net income and the equity.
\
Therefore, the sustainable growth rate is directly proportional to the ROE indicating that as the ROE increases, the sustainable growth rate increases and as the ROE decreases, the sustainable growth rate decreases as well.
To arrive at the sustainable growth rate, we are to determine the accounting rate of return and the retention ratio of the company.

## Accounting Return on Equity
\
Accounting Return on Equity is referred to as the financial measure of the company's financial performance. The ROE is computed by dividing the net income of the company by the total equity.
\
The return on equity is computed using the following formula:
 
$$\text{Return on Equity}=\frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Total Equity}}$$

## Retention Ratio
\
The retention ratio is referred to as the rate of the net income that is included in the retained earnings and is used to grow the business.
\
The retention ratio is computed using the following formula:
&nsbp;
$$\text{Retention Ratio}=\frac{\text{Retained Earnings}}{\text{Net Income}}\times100$$

Now, the formula to compute the sustainable growth rate is as follows:
 
$$\text{Sustainable Growth Rate}=\frac{\text{ROE} \times b}{1-\text{ROE}\times b}\times 100$$
Where:

ROE= Rate of Return
*b*= Retention Ratio

The computed sustainable growth rate under the three assumptions results in the same rate of sustainable growth. This is due to the fact that despite the difference in the amount of equity used in the calculation, the formulas used are modified in accordance with the assumption of the equity used to arrive at the sustainable growth rate.
In this task, we are asked to derive two versions sustainable growth rate formula.

The **Sustainable Growth Rate** is the highest growth rate that a company is capable of achieving with no additional equity funding from outside sources while yet maintaining the same debt-to-equity ratio. A company's sustainable growth rate tells you where it is in its life cycle. Looking into the company's long-term growth rate will allow an investor to make an informed decision about whether or not to invest.

The **Internal Growth Rate** is defined as the growth rate that a company can achieve through its financial resources without taking any external financing. As a result, the corporation relies completely on retained profits to keep operations running.

The sustainable growth rate is calculated in following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{SGR}=\dfrac{\text{ROE}_{\text{}}\cdot \text{b}}{1-(\text{ROE})\cdot \text{b}}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

SGR = Sustainable Growth Rate

ROE = Return on Equity

b = Retention Ratio

The internal growth rate is calculated in following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{IGR}&=\dfrac{\text{ROA}\cdot\text{b}}{1-(\text{ROA}\cdot\text{b})}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

IGR = Internal Growth Rate

ROA = Return On Assets

b = Retention Ratio

Formula for calculating return on equity is calculated by dividing net income by total equity as follows:

$$\text{ROE}=\dfrac{\text{NI}}{\text{TE}}$$

Where:

ROE = Return on Equity

NI = Net Income

TE = Total Equity

Formula for calculating return on assets is calculated by dividing net income by total assets as follows:

$$\text{ROA}=\dfrac{\text{NI}}{\text{TA}}$$

Where:

ROA = Return on Assets

NI = Net Income

TA = Total Assets

First, we will derive the first version of the formula for the sustainable growth rate, in which ROE is based on capital at the beginning of the period. In the original formula used to determine the sustainable growth rate from step 4, we will replace the ROE with the equation that calculates the ROE. The index "e" represent end of the period  and index "b" represent beginning of period.

$$\begin{align*}
\text{SGR}&=\dfrac{\text{ROE}_{\text{e}}\cdot\text{b}}{1-(\text{ROE}_{\text{e}}\cdot\text{b})}\\[20pt]
&=\dfrac{\dfrac{\text{NI}_{}}{\text{TE}_{\text{e}}}\cdot\text{b}}{1-\bigg(\dfrac{\text{NI}}{\text{TE}_{\text{e}}}\cdot\text{b}\bigg)} \\[35pt]
&=\dfrac{\dfrac{\text{NI}_{}}{\text{TE}_{\text{e}}}\cdot\text{b}}{1-\bigg(\dfrac{\text{NI}}{\text{TE}_{\text{e}}}\cdot\text{b}\bigg)}\cdot \dfrac{\text{TE}_{\text{e}}}{\text{TE}_{\text{e}}} \\[35pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{NI}\cdot\text{b}}{\text{TE}_{\text{e}}\cdot(\text{NI}\cdot\text{b})}
\end{align*}$$

We can notice that the denominator equals the equity at the beginning of the period, so:

$$\text{TE}_{b}=\text{TE}_{\text{e}}\cdot(\text{NI}\cdot\text{b})$$

To prove second version of the sustainable growth rate, in the original formula used to determine the internal growth rate from step 5, we will replace the ROA with the equation that calculates the ROA. The index "e" represent end of the period  and index "b" represent beginning of period.


$$\begin{align*}
\text{IGR}&=\dfrac{\text{ROA}_{\text{e}}\cdot\text{b}}{1-(\text{ROA}_{\text{e}}\cdot\text{b})}\\[20pt]
&=\dfrac{\dfrac{\text{NI}_{}}{\text{TA}_{\text{e}}}\cdot\text{b}}{1-\bigg(\dfrac{\text{NI}}{\text{TA}_{\text{e}}}\cdot\text{b}\bigg)} \\[35pt]
&=\dfrac{\dfrac{\text{NI}_{}}{\text{TA}_{\text{e}}}\cdot\text{b}}{1-\bigg(\dfrac{\text{NI}}{\text{TA}_{\text{e}}}\cdot\text{b}\bigg)}\cdot \dfrac{\text{TA}_{\text{e}}}{\text{TA}_{\text{e}}} \\[35pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{NI}\cdot\text{b}}{\text{TA}_{\text{e}}\cdot(\text{NI}\cdot\text{b})}
\end{align*}$$

We can notice that the denominator equals the assets at the beginning of the period, so:

$$\text{TA}_{b}=\text{TA}_{\text{e}}\cdot(\text{NI}\cdot\text{b})$$

Now we will substitute assets at the beginning of the period into obtained equation from step 8 in the following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{IGR}&=\dfrac{\text{NI}\cdot\text{b}}{\text{TA}_{\text{b}}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{NI}}{\text{TA}_{\text{b}}}\cdot\text{b}
\end{align*}$$

Which is equivalent to:

$$\text{SGR}=\dfrac{\text{NI}}{\text{TA}_{\text{b}}}\cdot\text{b}$$
